isis.stitle: HEAT VENTILATION AIR CONDITIONING (HVAC), Orifice Tube System, Pre-March 2007 - 3200, 4100, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 7600, 7700, 8500, 8600 - AC REFRIGERANT THERMISTOR CIRCUITS - FAULT DETECTION MANAGEMENT

svcproc.title: FAULT DETECTION MANAGEMENT

note.para: The testing method for troubleshooting the electrical systems covered in this manual is a basic voltage test. An alternate method of checking for voltage drops within a given circuit may be a quicker method of identifying an exact problem.

svcproc.para: This section describes the symptoms that may result from a failure in the refrigerant thermistor circuits. A list of the possible causes of the circuit failure is also provided. Table 36 lists and describes any Diagnostic Trouble Codes associated with the refrigerant thermistor circuits. Table 37 provides the troubleshooting procedures for isolating the cause of the failure.

A failure in the refrigerant thermistor circuits could be attributed to an open or short in the circuits between the thermistors and the ESC; an open or shorted thermistor; or a problem in the ESC. Refer to the REFRIGERANT THERMISTOR CIRCUITS diagram.
The ESC will log a diagnostic trouble code (DTC) for either a shorted thermistor circuit or an open thermistor circuit.

note.para: If the electrical connection to either thermistor is suspected of being intermittent, perform the THERMISTOR CONNECTOR REPAIR procedures . Then reconnect the connector and verify that the condition still exists before proceeding with troubleshooting.

svcproc.para: An electronic service tool, running diagnostic software, can be used to monitor thermistor inputs to the ESC. See the diagnostic software manual for details on using the software.

table.title: Refrigerant Thermistor Circuits Diagnostic Trouble Codes

entry.para: Outlet thermistor out of range low
This diagnostic code could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: a short to ground (or the 0 Volt Reference) in the circuits between the outlet thermistor and the ESC
a shorted thermistor
a problem in the ESC

entry.para: Outlet thermistor out of range high
This diagnostic code could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: an open in the circuit between the 0 Volt Reference and the outlet thermistor
an open in the circuit between the outlet thermistor and the ESC
an open thermistor
a problem in the ESC

entry.para: Inlet thermistor out of range low
This diagnostic code could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: a short to ground (or the 0 Volt Reference) in the circuits between the inlet thermistor and the ESC
a shorted thermistor
a problem in the ESC

entry.para: Inlet thermistor out of range high
This diagnostic code could be the result of any of the following conditions:

item.para: an open in the circuit between the 0 Volt Reference and the outlet thermistor
an open in the circuit between the outlet thermistor and the ESC
a shorted thermistor
a problem in the ESC

figure.caption: Figure 73. Refrigerant Thermistor Circuits-Always Refer to Circuit Diagram Book for Latest Circuit Information

calloutgroup.callout1: (4004) 36-WAY ELECTRICAL SYSTEM CONTROLLER CONNECTOR LOCATED ON ENGINE COMPARTMENT SIDE OF ESC
(4018) REFRIGERANT TEMPERATURE OUTLET THERMISTOR LOCATED ON TOP OF ACCUMULATOR
(4019) REFRIGERANT TEMPERATURE INLET THERMISTOR LOCATED NEAR BOTTOM OF EVAPORATOR
(4830) ZERO VOLT REFERENCE SPLICE LOCATED NEAR WIPER MOTOR BRACKET

entry.para: Install breakout box ZTSE4477 between connector (4004) and the ESC.
Check with Key ON and refrigerant thermistor connector (4019) disconnected from thermistor.

note.para: Always use breakout box ZTSE4477 to take measurements on ESC connectors.
Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.
When making resistance checks (for short circuits), always remove power and isolate the circuit being checked.

entry.para: Test Points
Spec.
Comments
(4019) harness connector, cavity A to ground.
10 ± 1 volt.
If voltage is correct, go to next step.
If voltage is incorrect check for:

item.para: a short circuit between (4019) cavity A and ground
a short circuit between (4019) cavity A and cavity B (0 Volt Ref)

note.para: If a short circuit is present, isolate the short to the circuit or the ESC.

item.para: an open circuit between (4019) cavity A and ESC connector (4004) terminal 7

entry.para: If the voltage is incorrect and no open or shorted circuits are present, replace the ESC.
(4019) harness connector, cavity A to cavity B.
10 ± 1 volt.
If voltage is correct, go to next step.
If voltage is incorrect, check for open circuits between (4019) cavity B and ESC connector (4004) terminal 26. If no open circuit exists, replace the ESC.
Check with Key off.
Reconnect the thermistor connector (4019) to the thermistor.
The thermistor harness (4004) must be connected to the breakout box, but the breakout box should be disconnected from the ESC.

note.para: Always use breakout box ZTSE4477 to take measurements on ESC connectors.
Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.
When making resistance checks (for short circuits), always remove power and isolate the circuit being checked.

entry.para: Connector (4019) contacts A and B, to ground (metal A/C line).

note.para: To prevent damage to the thermistor pins, these resistances can be measured from contacts 7 and 26, respectively, on the breakout box. Breakout box must be disconnected from ESC.

entry.para: Check for short circuits.
If either circuit is shorted to ground, replace the thermistor.
If no short circuits are present, go to next step.
Connector (4019) contact A to contact B

note.para: To prevent damage to the thermistor pins, this value can be measured between contacts 7 and 26, on the breakout box. Breakout box must be disconnected from ESC.

entry.para: Resistance value

Measure resistance. Look up equivalent temperature value in THERMISTOR CROSS REFERENCE TABLE, and compare to approximate temperature of A/C line (measure with temperature probe, if available). If temperature readings disagree, replace the thermistor. If the temperature readings agree, replace the ESC.
Install breakout box ZTSE4477 between connector (4004) and the ESC.
Check with Key ON and refrigerant thermistor connector (4018) disconnected from thermistor.

note.para: Always use breakout box ZTSE4477 to take measurements on ESC connectors.
Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.
When making resistance checks (for short circuits), always remove power and isolate the circuit being checked.

entry.para: Test Points
Spec.
Comments
(4018) harness connector, cavity A to ground.
10 ± 1 volt.
If voltage is correct, go to next step.
If voltage is incorrect check for:

item.para: a short circuit between (4018) cavity A and ground
a short circuit between (4018) cavity A and cavity B (0 Volt Ref)

note.para: If a short circuit is present, isolate the short to the circuit or the ESC.

item.para: an open circuit between (4018) cavity A and ESC connector (4004) terminal 6

entry.para: If the voltage is incorrect and no open or shorted circuits are present, replace the ESC.
(4018) harness connector, cavity A to cavity B.
10 ± 1 volt.
If voltage is correct, go to next step.
If voltage is incorrect, check for open circuits between (4018) cavity B and ESC connector (4004) terminal 26. If no open circuit exists, replace the ESC.
Check with Key off.
Reconnect the thermistor connector (4018) to the thermistor.
The thermistor harness (4004) must be connected to the breakout box, but the breakout box should be disconnected from the ESC.

note.para: Always use breakout box ZTSE4477 to take measurements on ESC connectors.
Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.
When making resistance checks (for short circuits), always remove power and isolate the circuit being checked.

entry.para: Connector (4018) contacts A and B, to ground (metal A/C line).

note.para: To prevent damage to the thermistor pins, these resistances can be measured from contacts 6 and 26, respectively, on the breakout box. Breakout box must be disconnected from ESC.

entry.para: Check for short circuits.
If either circuit is shorted to ground, replace the thermistor.
If no short circuits are present, go to next step.
Connector (4018) contact A to contact B

note.para: To prevent damage to the thermistor pins, this value can be measured between contacts 6 and 26, on the breakout box. Breakout box must be disconnected from ESC.

entry.para: Resistance value

Measure resistance. Look up equivalent temperature value in THERMISTOR CROSS REFERENCE TABLE, and compare to approximate temperature of A/C line (measure with temperature probe, if available). If temperature readings disagree, replace the thermistor. If the temperature readings agree replace the ESC.
Note 1:
Thermistor voltages are nominal and will vary with the ignition voltage.
